greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: A028234 analog for factorization process based on the sieve of Eratosthenes (A083221).
comment: Iterating n, a(n), a(a(n)), a(a(a(n))), ..., until 1 is reached, and taking the smallest prime factor (A020639) of each term gives a sequence of distinct primes in ascending order, while applying A302045 to the same terms gives the corresponding exponents (multiplicities) of those primes. Permutation pair A250245/A250246 maps between this non-standard prime factorization and the ordinary factorization of n. See also comments and examples in A302042.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
Index entries for sequences generated by sieves
formula: For n > 1, a(n) = A250469^(r)(A000265(A078898(n))), where r = A055396(n)-1 and A250469^(r)(n) stands for applying r times the map x -> A250469(x), starting from x = n.
program: \\ Assuming A250469 and its inverse A268674 have been precomputed, then the following is fast enough:

ordinal_transform(invec) = { my(om = Map(), outvec = vector(length(invec)), pt); for(i=1, length(invec), if(mapisdefined(om,invec[i]), pt = mapget(om, invec[i]), pt = 0); outvec[i] = (1+pt); mapput(om,invec[i],(1+pt))); outvec; };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 31 2018
